title: Warburton strikes his first deal, don't expect it to be the last
text:
Friday's deals were the first for Warburton at Seven, ending a months-long pursuit of Prime which began back when he was leading a consortium with private equity to take over the business. It may be increasing Seven’s exposure to broadcast TV, but it provides a larger audience for advertisers, significant revenue synergy opportunities to take national advertisers into regional Australia, building on the Boomtown campaign, and adds more earnings largely without debt which will help Seven with its significant debt pile without increasing it via a cash offer acquisition.

But now that Warburton finally has his target, don’t expect this to be his last transaction. Seven still needs to build more scale outside of television, particularly digital to adapt to the rapidly evolving media landscape.

It’s right out of former Fairfax CEO Greg Hywood's playbook. Cut costs, sell non-core assets, reduce debt, and look for new revenue opportunities.

Where Warburton is looking to move next only he can be sure. Even with asset sales, Seven’s balance sheet still needs fixing. He will need to be creative. Nil-premium mergers and scrip offers may be the main ingredient in the recipe to turn around Seven by building a large, at scale, multi-platform media business.

Interesting possibility

Combining Seven with outdoor advertiser oOh!media and FM radio network and music streaming business HT &E could be an interesting possibility and there are probably $30 million to $40 million in synergies that could be pulled out.

The former Network Ten boss has his detractors, particularly after his time at the No. 3 metropolitan broadcaster. But there are clear signs he has learned lessons from his failures – one being his strength isn’t programming, so he’s opened Seven for business with independent studios again and is hunting for a chief content officer.

Warburton has been given the rope to tackle Seven’s big issues – as Chanticleer points out balancing the dual roles of transforming the company with the Stokes’ backing but without getting capital from the major shareholder Seven Group Holdings.

He’s hit the ground running. Don’t expect him to stand still.
description: James Warburton has locked in his first two deals as chief executive of Seven West Media but they're unlikely to be his last..
